bioghist.head: Biography of Alden Nash
bioghist.p: Alden Nash (1903-1996) was a playwright and screenwriter. Filmography includes the comedy We’re Rich Again (1934) that was adapted from Nash’s play And Let Who Will be Clever; uncredited dialogue writer for Gridiron Flash (1934), uncredited contributing writer for Magnificent Obsession (1935), story writer for Passport to Suez (1943), playwright for The Sainted Sisters (1948), adaptation of Man-Eater of Kumaon (1948) and screenwriter for Unwed Mother (1958).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence between Nash and California and national lawmakers regarding the depressed state of the movie industry during the 1970s and ideas to combat the issue, a 140-page screenplay by Nash titled “Ten Little Kidnappers;” an article by Arnold M. Auerbach titled “He’s Flunking Buster Keaton!,” which is a satirical essay on the study of film; and a letter to the editor written by Nash that appeared in a publication of the Writers Guild of America, West, explaining and defending the Guild.
